source.042cdc9e:
fig = plt.figure(figsize=(20,8),facecolor="whitesmoke")
#  subplot #1
plt.subplot(212)
plt.title('Indians distribution as per gender and their Education')
sns.countplot(x="What is your gender? - Selected Choice",data= India_reponses,palette="Reds_r",
              hue="What is the highest level of formal education that you have attained or plan to attain within the next 2 years?")
plt.legend(loc="upper right")

#  subplot #2
plt.subplot(211)
plt.title('World distribution as per gender')
sns.countplot(x="What is your gender? - Selected Choice",data= other_responses,palette="Blues")
ax=sns.countplot(x="What is your gender? - Selected Choice",data=India_reponses,color="firebrick",
                 order=India_reponses["What is your gender? - Selected Choice"].value_counts().index)
for p, label in zip(ax.patches, India_reponses["What is your gender? - Selected Choice"].value_counts().values):
    ax.annotate(label, (p.get_x()+0.375, p.get_height()-0.15))
plt.legend(["World","Indians"])
plt.tight_layout(pad=5)
plt.suptitle("Count as per gender",fontsize=20)
plt.show()
source.223747c4:
india=pd.DataFrame(India_reponses.iloc[:,4:6].value_counts()).rename(columns={0:"India_counts"})
world=pd.DataFrame(other_responses.iloc[:,4:6].value_counts()).rename(columns={0:"World_counts"})
merged_data=pd.merge(india, world, on=['What is the highest level of formal education that you have attained or plan to attain within the next 2 years?',
                                       'Select the title most similar to your current role (or most recent title if retired): - Selected Choice'], how='left').reset_index()
fig,axs=plt.subplots(1,2,figsize=(15,20),sharey=True)
sns.barplot(x="India_counts",y="What is the highest level of formal education that you have attained or plan to attain within the next 2 years?"
           ,hue="Select the title most similar to your current role (or most recent title if retired): - Selected Choice",data=merged_data,ax=axs[0],palette="Reds_r")
axs[0].set_title("India")
axs[0].set_ylabel("Highest level of formal education",fontsize=15)
axs[0].set_xlim([0, 3750])
axs[0].invert_xaxis()
plt.legend([],[], frameon=False)
sns.barplot(x="World_counts",y="What is the highest level of formal education that you have attained or plan to attain within the next 2 years?"
           ,hue="Select the title most similar to your current role (or most recent title if retired): - Selected Choice",data=merged_data,ax=axs[1],palette="Blues_r")
axs[1].set_title("Rest of World")
axs[1].set_ylabel('', labelpad=25)
plt.suptitle("India Vs Rest of World",fontsize=20)
fig.legend(bbox_to_anchor=(0, 1.05),title="Kagglers job description",fancybox=True,title_fontsize=12)
fig.text(0.5, 0.04, 'Counts of Kagglers in World and India', ha='center',fontsize=15)
for ax in axs:
    ax.legend([],[], frameon=False)  
plt.subplots_adjust(wspace=0)
plt.show()

from matplotlib import gridspec
ex_language=pd.melt(India_reponses.iloc[:,6:20], id_vars=["For how many years have you been writing code and/or programming?"],
                    value_vars=India_reponses.iloc[:,6:20].columns.tolist()[1:])
fig9 = plt.figure(constrained_layout=False,figsize=(25,10),facecolor="whitesmoke")
gs2 = fig9.add_gridspec(nrows=3, ncols=3,hspace=0.05,wspace=0.65)
sns.set_style("whitegrid")
ax0 = fig9.add_subplot(gs2[:, :-1])
sns.countplot(y="value",hue="For how many years have you been writing code and/or programming?",data=ex_language,palette="Accent",ax=ax0)
ax0.set_title("Experience Indian Programmers choose which language")
ax0.legend(loc="lower right",title="Experience in programming")
ax1 = fig9.add_subplot(gs2[:-1, -1])
India_reponses[India_reponses["What programming languages do you use on a regular basis? (Select all that apply) - Selected Choice - Python"]==
               "Python"]["Select the title most similar to your current role (or most recent title if retired): - Selected Choice"].value_counts().plot.barh(ax=ax1,color="skyblue")
India_reponses[India_reponses["What programming languages do you use on a regular basis? (Select all that apply) - Selected Choice - SQL"]
               =="SQL"]["Select the title most similar to your current role (or most recent title if retired): - Selected Choice"].value_counts().plot.barh(ax=ax1,color="red",alpha=0.70)
ax1.legend(["Python","SQL"],loc="upper right")
ax1.set_title("Profession like Python and Sql")

ax2 = fig9.add_subplot(gs2[-1, -1])
India_reponses[India_reponses["What programming languages do you use on a regular basis? (Select all that apply) - Selected Choice - Python"]==
               "Python"]["What is your gender? - Selected Choice"].value_counts().plot.barh(ax=ax2,color="skyblue")
India_reponses[India_reponses["What programming languages do you use on a regular basis? (Select all that apply) - Selected Choice - SQL"]
               =="SQL"]["What is your gender? - Selected Choice"].value_counts().plot.barh(ax=ax2,color="red",alpha=0.70)
ax2.legend(["Python","SQL"],loc="upper right")
ax2.set_title("Gender like Python and Sql", y=-0.3)

plt.setp(ax.get_xticklabels(), fontsize=8)
gs2.tight_layout(fig9)
plt.suptitle("Indian Programming Language choice",y=1.05,fontsize=20)
plt.show()

source.646007af:
def color(x): #for making  color pivot table
    c1 = 'background-color: yellow'
    c2 = 'background-color: red'
    c = ''
    m1 = x.columns.str.startswith('AA')
    m2 = x.columns.str.startswith('AB')

    df1 = pd.DataFrame(c, index=x.index, columns=x.columns)
    df1.loc[:, m1] = c1
    df1.loc[:, m2] = c2
    return df1
source.4987c9c2:
#Classes for the subplots graph 
def graph_1(col1,value1,value2,col2,ax):# for overlapping bar graphs
    India_reponses[India_reponses[col1]==
                      value1][col2].value_counts().plot.barh(ax=ax)
    India_reponses[India_reponses[col1]
                   ==value2][col2].value_counts().plot.barh(ax=ax,color="yellow",alpha=0.70)
    return plt.show()

def graph_2(ax,data): #for treemap
    new_data=data.rename(columns={0: 'COUNT'}).reset_index().groupby("value")["COUNT"].sum()
    squarify.plot(new_data.values,color=colors, label = new_data.keys(),pad=0.1,ax=ax)
    plt.axis("off")

def graph_3(df_summary_table):
    df_summary_table.style.apply(color,axis=None)
     
def graph_4(new_data):
     plt.pie(new_data.values, labels = new_data.keys(),autopct ='% 1.1f %%', shadow = True)
     plt.show()
 
def graph_5(fig,df2,c1,c2,c3,value):
    fig = px.treemap(df2, path=[px.Constant("all"),c1,c2,c3], 
                 values=0, color=c3)
    fig.update_layout(margin = dict(t=50, l=25, r=25, b=25))
    return fig.show()
     
def graph_6(names,size):
#names = df2.groupby("What type of computing platform do you use most often for your data science projects? - Selected Choice").sum()[0].keys()
#size = df2.groupby("What type of computing platform do you use most often for your data science projects? - Selected Choice").sum()[0].values
    lab=[f'{dismiss}\n{no}' for dismiss, no in zip(names, size)]
    my_circle = plt.Circle( (0,0), 0.7, color='white')
    plt.pie(size, labels=lab, colors=['red','green','blue','skyblue'])
    p = plt.gcf()
    p.gca().add_artist(my_circle)
    plt.show()
    
def graph_7(outer,size,inner,inner_labels):
    ax.pie(outer.values.flatten(), radius=1,
       labels=outer.index,
       autopct='%1.1f%%',
       wedgeprops=dict(width=size, edgecolor='w'))
    
    ax.pie(inner.values.flatten(), radius=1-size, 
       labels = inner_labels,
       wedgeprops=dict(width=size, edgecolor='w'))
    
    ax.set(aspect="equal", title='Pie plot with `ax.pie`')
    plt.show()
    
def graph_8(variable,value,category,ax):
    fig=(ggplot(df, aes(x=variable, y=value, fill=category))
     + geom_col()
       )
    ax=fig
    return ax

def graph_9(dodge_text,ccolor,variable,value,category,pos="dodge"):
    (ggplot(df, aes(x=variable, y=value, fill=category))
     + geom_col(stat='identity', position=pos, show_legend=False)
     + geom_text(aes(y=-.5, label='category'),
                 position=dodge_text,
                 color=ccolor, size=6, angle=45, va='top')              # modified
     + geom_text(aes(label='value'),
                 position=dodge_text,
                 size=6,va='bottom', format_string='{}%')
     + lims(y=(-5, 60))
     + theme(panel_background=element_rect(fill='white'),               # new
             axis_title_y=element_blank(),
             axis_line_x=element_line(color='black'),
             axis_line_y=element_blank(),
             axis_text_y=element_blank(),
             axis_text_x=element_text(color=ccolor),
             axis_ticks_major_y=element_blank(),
             panel_grid=element_blank(),
             panel_border=element_blank())
    )
    
def graph_11(data,col1,col2,col3,ax):
    mon = data[col1].unique()  # Months ordered January, ..., December
    data[col1]= pd.Categorical(data[col1], categories=months)
    fig =(ggplot(flights, aes('factor(col3)', col1, fill=col2))
          + geom_tile(aes(width=.95, height=.95))
          + geom_text(aes(label='col2'), size=10)
         )
    ax=fig
    return ax

def graph_12(data,ax):
    sns.heatmap(data, annot=True, fmt="d", linewidths=.5, ax=ax)
    
def graph_13(labels,values,ax):
    fig = go.Figure(data=[go.Pie(labels=labels, values=values, hole=.3)])
    ax=fig
    return ax.show()

def graph_14(data,value,name,title,h_d,label,ax):
    fig = px.pie(df, values=value, names=name,
                 title='title',
                 hover_data=[h_d], labels=label)
    fig.update_traces(textposition='inside', textinfo='percent+label')
    ax=fig
    return ax.show

def graph_15(data,col1,col2,col3):
    fig = px.bar(df, x=col1, y=col2, color=col3,
             pattern_shape="nation")
    fig.show()
    
def graph_16(df,col1,col2,col3,col4):
    fig = px.icicle(df, path=[px.Constant("all"), col1, col2, col3],
                values=col4, color=col3)
    fig.update_layout(margin = dict(t=50, l=25, r=25, b=25))
    fig.show()
    
def graph_17(df,col1,col2,col3,col4):
    fig = px.sunburst(df, path=[col1, col2, col3], values=col4)
    fig.show()
    
def graph_18(df,col1,col2,col3,col4,order):
    fig = px.bar(df, x=col1, y=col4, color=col2, barmode="group", facet_col=col3,
             category_orders=order)
    fig.show()
source.f889d2be:
#class for the creation of multiple plots
class My_plot:
    def __init__(self, ncols, nrows,fig,_figsize,value,hue,hue2,palette,facecolor="whitesmoke",
                 colors=[k for k,v in matplotlib.colors.cnames.items()][35:50]):
        self.nrows = nrows
        self.ncols = ncols
        self.fig = fig
        self._figsize=_figsize
        self.value=value
        self.hue=hue
        self.hue2=hue2
        self.palette=palette
        self.facecolor=facecolor
        self.colors=colors
    
    def my_plot1(self,t_1,t_2,t_3,t_4,data1,data2,data3,data4,sup):
        self.fig = plt.figure(constrained_layout=True,figsize=self._figsize,facecolor=self.facecolor)
        spec2 = matplotlib.gridspec.GridSpec(ncols=self.ncols, nrows=self.nrows, figure=self.fig)
        f_ax1 = self.fig.add_subplot(spec2[0, 0])
        f_ax1 = sns.countplot(y=self.value,hue=self.hue,data=data1,palette=self.palette)
        f_ax1.set_title("{0}".format(t_1))
        f_ax1.legend(loc="best",title="Experience in programming")
        f_ax1.set_ylabel("")
        plt.tick_params(axis='both', which='both',labelsize=6)
        f_ax2 = self.fig.add_subplot(spec2[0, 1])
        f_ax2 = sns.countplot(y=self.value,hue=self.hue,data=data2,palette=self.palette)
        f_ax2.set_title("{0}".format(t_2))
        f_ax2.legend(loc="best",title="Experience in programming")
        f_ax2.set_ylabel("")
        plt.tick_params(axis='y', which='both', labelleft=False, labelright=True , left=False, right=True,labelsize=6)
        f_ax3 = self.fig.add_subplot(spec2[1, 0])
        f_ax3 = sns.countplot(y=self.value,hue=self.hue,data=data3,palette=self.palette)
        f_ax3.set_title("{0}".format(t_3))
        f_ax3.legend(loc="best",title="Experience in programming")
        f_ax3.set_ylabel("")
        plt.tick_params(axis='both', which='both',labelsize=6)
        f_ax4 = self.fig.add_subplot(spec2[1, 1])
        f_ax4 = sns.countplot(y=self.value,hue=self.hue,data=data4,palette=self.palette)
        f_ax4.set_title("{0}".format(t_4))
        f_ax4.legend(loc="best",title="Experience in programming")
        f_ax4.set_ylabel("")
        plt.tick_params(axis='both', which='both', labelleft=False, labelright=True , left=False, right=True,labelsize=6)
        self.fig.suptitle(sup, size=20)
        return plt.show()
        
    def my_plot2(self,t_1,t_2,t_3,t_4,t_5,data1,data2,data3,data4,data5,sup):
        self.fig = plt.figure(constrained_layout=True,figsize=self._figsize,facecolor=self.facecolor)
        gs = self.fig.add_gridspec(self.nrows, self.ncols)
        f_ax1 = self.fig.add_subplot(gs[0, :])
        f_ax1 = sns.countplot(y=self.value,hue=self.hue,data=data1,palette=self.palette)
        f_ax1.set_title("Experience Indian Programmers choose which {0}".format(t_1))
        f_ax1.legend(loc="best",title="Experience in programming")
        f_ax2 = self.fig.add_subplot(gs[1, :-1])
        data2.plot.bar(ax=f_ax2);
        f_ax2.set_title('gs[1, :-1]')
        f_ax3 = self.fig.add_subplot(gs[1:, -1])
        data3.plot.bar(ax=f_ax3);
        f_ax3.set_title('gs[1:, -1]')
        f_ax4 = self.fig.add_subplot(gs[-1, 0])
        data4.plot.bar(ax=f_ax4);
        f_ax4.set_title('gs[-1, 0]')
        f_ax5 = self.fig.add_subplot(gs[-1, -2])
        data5.plot.bar(ax=f_ax5);
        f_ax5.set_title('gs[-1, -2]')
        self.fig.suptitle(sup, size=20)
        
    def my_plot3(self,t_1,t_2,t_3,data1,data2,data3,sup,sizes,labels):
        self.fig = plt.figure(constrained_layout=True,figsize=self._figsize,facecolor=self.facecolor)
        gs1 = self.fig.add_gridspec(nrows=self.nrows, ncols=self.ncols, left=0.05, right=0.48, wspace=0.05)
        
        f_ax1 = self.fig.add_subplot(gs1[:-1, :])
        f_ax1 = sns.countplot(y=self.value,hue=self.hue,data=data1,palette=self.palette)
        f_ax1.set_title("{0}".format(t_1))
        f_ax1.legend(loc="best",title="Experience in programming")
        plt.tick_params(axis='both', which='both',labelsize=6)
        
        f_ax2 = self.fig.add_subplot(gs1[-1, :-1])

        
        f_ax3 = self.fig.add_subplot(gs1[-1, -1])
   
       
    
    def my_plot4(self,t_1,t_2,data1,data2,data3,sup,lt1,lt2,lt3):
        self.fig = plt.figure(constrained_layout=True,figsize=self._figsize,facecolor=self.facecolor)
        gs2 = self.fig.add_gridspec(nrows=self.nrows, ncols=self.ncols, left=0.05, right=0.48, wspace=0.05)
        
        f_ax1 = self.fig.add_subplot(gs2[:, :-1])
        f_ax1 = sns.countplot(y=self.value,hue=self.hue,data=data1,palette=self.palette)
        f_ax1.set_title("{0}".format(t_1))
        f_ax1.legend(loc="best",title=lt1)
        f_ax1.set_ylabel("")
        plt.tick_params(axis='both', which='both',labelsize=6)
        
        gs01 = gs2[:-1, -1].subgridspec(1,2)
        ax4 = self.fig.add_subplot(gs01[-1, :-1])
        ax5 = self.fig.add_subplot(gs01[-1, -1])        
        labels = ind1[ind1["What is your gender? - Selected Choice"]=="Man"].groupby([self.value])["For how many years have you been writing code and/or programming?"].count().keys()
        values = ind1[ind1["What is your gender? - Selected Choice"]=="Man"].groupby([self.value])["For how many years have you been writing code and/or programming?"].count().values
        ax4.pie(values,labels = labels,colors = self.colors,autopct = '%1.1f%%',textprops={'fontsize': 6}) #plot first pie
        ax4.set_title('Indian Man choose')


        labels = ind1[ind1["What is your gender? - Selected Choice"]=="Woman"].groupby([self.value])["For how many years have you been writing code and/or programming?"].count().keys()
        values = ind1[ind1["What is your gender? - Selected Choice"]=="Woman"].groupby([self.value])["For how many years have you been writing code and/or programming?"].count().values
        ax5.pie(values,labels = labels,colors = self.colors,autopct = '%1.1f%%',textprops={'fontsize': 6}) #plot second pie
        ax5.set_title('Indian Woman choose')

        f_ax3 = self.fig.add_subplot(gs2[-1, -1])
        f_ax3 = sns.countplot(y=self.value,hue=self.hue2,data=data3,palette=self.palette)
        f_ax3.set_title("{0}".format(t_2))
        f_ax3.legend(loc="best",title=lt3)
        f_ax3.set_ylabel("")
        plt.tick_params(axis='both', which='both', labelleft=False, labelright=True , left=False, right=True,labelsize=6)
        
        self.fig.suptitle(sup, size=20)
        return plt.show()
    
    def my_plot5(self,data1,t_1,lt1,lg,t2,t3,y1,y2,sup_font,sup_title):
        
        self.fig = plt.figure(constrained_layout=True,figsize=self._figsize,facecolor=self.facecolor)
        gs2 = self.fig.add_gridspec(nrows=self.nrows, ncols=self.ncols, left=0.05, right=0.48, wspace=0.05)
        
        f_ax1 = self.fig.add_subplot(gs2[:, :-1])
        f_ax1 = sns.countplot(y=self.value,hue=self.hue,data=data1,palette=self.palette)
        f_ax1.set_title("{0}".format(t_1))
        f_ax1.legend(loc="best",title=lt1)
        f_ax1.set_ylabel("")
        plt.tick_params(axis='both', which='both',labelsize=6)
        
        f_ax2 = self.fig.add_subplot(gs2[:-1, -1])
        graph_1(col1,value1,value2,col2,f_ax3)
        f_ax2.legend(lg,loc="best")
        f_ax2.set_title(t2)

        f_ax3 = self.fig.add_subplot(gs2[-1, -1])
        graph_1(col1,value1,value2,col2,f_ax3)
        f_ax3.legend(lg,loc="best")
        f_ax3.set_title(t3, y=y1)

        plt.setp(ax.get_xticklabels(), fontsize=8)
        gs2.tight_layout(self.fig)
        plt.suptitle(sup_title,y=y2,fontsize=sup_font)
        plt.show()

source.0c5e7b90:
def solo_plot5(col,list1,grid,value,palette,title,l_l,l_r,l_t):
    data5=Making_data(col).making_data(list1)
    plt.figure(figsize=(20,10),facecolor="whitesmoke")
    sns.set_style(grid)
    sns.countplot(y=value,hue=col,data=data5,palette=palette)
    plt.title(title)
    plt.tick_params(axis='y', which='both', labelleft=l_l, labelright=l_r , left=False, right=True)
    plt.legend(loc="lower right",title=l_t,facecolor="white")
    sns.despine()
    plt.ylabel("")
    plt.xlabel("")
    return plt.show()

source.c5f8b5be: Most Indians taken less than 10 seconds to complete the survey.
source.37ee23e8: Indian which has : Gender Male,Age18-21 years,DegreeBachelor Degree,ProfessionStudent,Programming1-3 years is most active among the Indian Kaggler.
source.ec368c98:
Most Indians chooseCoursera, Kaggle learn Courses and Udemy as their first destination where they Completed their Data Science Courses.

Indian Kagglers top destination for media Courses that report on data science are Kaggle Youtube and Blogs .

Indians want to familiar with Amazon Web Services,Google Cloud Services and Microsoft Azure as their Cloud Computing Platform to learn ( within Next 2 years ).

Indians want to familiar with Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud, Google Cloud Compute Engine & Microsoft Azure Virtual Machines as their Cloud Computing Products that they learn ( within Next 2 years ).
source.a2213d48:
Men Kagglers have dominance in India alongside the rest of world.

Men Kagglers in India responsed 4 times more than Indian women and they have mostly Bachelors Degree .
source.47dffe0e: Indians have active Youth participation (below 29 years old category)
source.1d7b1786:
Indians want to familiar with Azure Machine Learning Studio, Amazon Sagemaker & Google Cloud vertex AI as their Machine learning products that they learn ( within Next 2 years ).

Indians want to familiar with MySQL, MongoDB and Google Cloud SQL as their Big data products that they learn ( within Next 2 years ).

Indians want to familiar with Tableau, Microsoft PowerBI and Google Data Studio as their Business Intelligence tools that they learn ( within Next 2 years ).

Indians want to familiar with Automated ML pipelines, Model selection and Data Augmentation as Automated Machine Learning Tools that they will learn and use ( within Next 2 years ).
source.a1787275: Student community with experience in programming having1-3 year or less than 1 year is prevelant over the Kaggle.
source.1b07cfe7: 45.4% responses came from Indian kagglers.This is approx. half of all responses came from all countries.
source.727a160e: Tell a data story about a subset of the data science community represented in this survey, through a combination of both narrative text and data exploration. A “story” could be defined any number of ways, and that’s deliberate. The challenge is to deeply explore (through data) the impact, priorities, or concerns of a specific group of data science and machine learning practitioners. That group can be defined in the macro (for example: anyone who does most of their coding in Python) or the micro (for example: female data science students studying machine learning in masters programs). This is an opportunity to be creative and tell the story of a community you identify with or are passionate about!
source.137481e6:
3 Popular languages choosen for Data science aspirants by all profession (as Recommendation) are :Python,SQL,R .

Woman choice for Python,SQL,R are:80.5%,5.8%,5.1% respectivaly over Man's choosen85%,3.7%,3.7% for the same.

Python mostly choosed by 1-3 years experienced Programmers,SQL mostly choosed by < 1 years experienced Programmers and R mostly choosed by 1-3 years and < 1 years equallyexperienced Programmers(who has Bachelor,Masters,Doctorate degree and is either Man or Woman).
source.db1712cc:
Python and SQL are the programming that Indians like most.Group having experience 1- 3 years are most enthusist among Indians.

Women's love of SQL over python is more than the Men.Participation of Student and Data Scientist is highest for choosing Python and SQL
source.9ba9448e: Indian along with Vietnam and Indonesia has 1/3rd of its Kaggle community aged between 18-21.
source.fb552a99:
Jupyter Notebook, Visual studio code,Pycharm are the popular IDEs among experienced as well as novice Indians.

Collab Notebooks,Kaggle Notebooks,Binder are the popular Notebooks among experienced as well as novice Indians.

None,Nvidia GPUs,Google Cloud TPUs are the popular chooses for hardware among experienced as well as novice Indians.

Matplotlib,Seaborn,Plotly,ggplot are the popular Data Visualization library among experienced as well as novice Indians.
source.05726a73:
Scikit-learn,Keras,Xgboost are the popular ML Library among Indians.

Linear/logistic along with Decision Tree and CNN are the most popular ML Algorithms among experienced as well as novice Indians.

Image classification using Networks,Object detection,general purpose image/video tools are the popular chooses for Computer vision method used among Indians.

Word embeding vectors along with encoding/decoding and Transformer are the most popular NLP method among Indians.
source.f95264b1:
Amazon Web Services,Google Cloud and Microsoft Azure are the most popular Cloud computing platforms in India.

Indians use None more often but other most popular Data storage products are Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud, Google Cloud Compute Engine & Simple Storage Service.

Indians use None more often but other most popular Machine Learning products are Azure Machine Learning Studio, Amazon Sagemaker & Databricks.

MySql,PostgresQL and MongoDB are the most popular Big Data products(databases) among Indians.
source.a2c73960:
Most Indians chooseNone as their 3rd alternative for Business Intelligence tools .But Topspot Grabbers are Tableau and PowerBI.

Automated Machine Learning tools are mostly used None but popular ones are for Auto model selection, Feature selection & data Augmentation.

Machine Learning experiment tools are mostly used None but popular ones are for TensorBoard,MLflow & Weights and Biases.

Github,Kaggle and Colab are the most popular Data Analysis and ML sharing appications among Indians.
source.6cba7601: Indian Kaggler's Favourite
